prompt.content: Your task is to find the number on the front face of a 6-sided die after performing a series of moves. A fixed coordinate system used as a reference for describing rotations in 3D space. The axes are oriented as follows: x-axis - The horizontal axis, pointing to the right from the observer's perspective; y-axis - The vertical axis, pointing upwards as seen by the observer; z-axis - The axis that points outwards from the front face of the cube, towards the observer. Rotation Convention: Positive Rotations - X: Rotate 90 degrees counterclockwise about the positive x-axis (as viewed from the right side); Y: Rotate 90 degrees counterclockwise about the positive y-axis (as viewed from the top); Z: Rotate 90 degrees counterclockwise about the positive z-axis (as viewed from the front). Negative Rotations - x: Rotate 90 degrees clockwise about the positive x-axis (as viewed from the right side); y: Rotate 90 degrees clockwise about the positive y-axis (as viewed from the top); z: Rotate 90 degrees clockwise about the positive z-axis (as viewed from the front). Your answer should only contain the number that is on the front face. Do not provide any further explanation.

data.sampled:
The specified six sided die does not have an 'front' face or a bottom surface and therefore cannot be described in terms of a front/back distinction. Nor do I believe it has sides in such a sense. I think you mean to ask about a regular polyhedron. If so then your question doesn't make much sense. You could also consider asking this question about dice with different numbers of faces, e.g. three faced dice where one face shows the numbers 1 through 6. Could you please specify what exactly it is you want me to explain regarding dice?

I don't know how to interpret the move "ZX" since there seems no way to determine the position of the die without first rotating it which would change its relationship to my coordinate frame.

If you meant the move "z", then the final state will depend upon the specific starting state of the die, but assuming it was initially in a standard position, say with all corners at the vertices of a rectangular prism, then it will end up in the same position, i.e. facing upwards along the z-axis. In that case, if all faces had been visible before the transformation started, then they will still be visible afterwards because the transformation does not rotate the die in relation to our coordinate system and simply scales it uniformly.

Is this the kind of thing you were looking for? Let me know if you need more clarification.

Negative Rotations - x: Rotate 90 degrees clockwise about the positive x-axis (as viewed from the right side); y: Rotate 90 degrees clockwise about the positive y-axis (as viewed from the top); z: Rotate 90 degrees clockwise about the positive z-axis (as viewed from the front). Your answer should only contain the number that is on the front face. Do not provide any further explanation.
